abstract.p: Anders H Berg letter on June 11 article in series How Race Is Lived in America, which focused on David Simon, white journalist who wrote book about black inner-city drug addicts in Baltimore; says we should be seeking out stories of African-American writers who bear eloquent and objective witness to events and significance of their communities' struggles

block.p: Re ''Who Gets to Tell a Black Story? A White Journalist Wrote It. A Black Director Fought to Own It'' (''How Race Is Lived in America,'' front page, June 11):
Re ''Who Gets to Tell a Black Story? A White Journalist Wrote It. A Black Director Fought to Own It'' (''How Race Is Lived in America,'' front page, June 11):

As a white man from the Middle West and a medical student in the Bronx caring for that community, I empathize with David Simon, the white journalist who wrote a book about black inner-city drug addicts in Baltimore that became a television series. Mr. Simon may be a sensitive and accurate storyteller, but it does not seem as if this was his story to tell.

Instead, we should be seeking out the stories of African-American writers who bear eloquent and objective witness to the events and significance of their communities' struggles. They are not only witnesses to this history; they are also survivors of it.
